title: Liberty Valance
content:
Hello,  
could anyone identify this font, please?  
It's from the John Ford's film "The man who shot Liberty Valance".

Thanks in advance!

David

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [typo liberty valance.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056/http:/typophile.com/files/typo%20liberty%20valance.jpg) | 54.94 KB |
author: epiney

comments.content:
Not a typeface, but hand lettering (as was most poster display type of the era).

The lettering appears to be based on an old woodtype style called Latin:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/latin/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/latin/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/latin/")

Some digital typefaces with a similar vibe (but by no means a match to your sample):  
 [http://www.houseind.com/fonts/edbenguiatfonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056/http:/www.houseind.com/fonts/edbenguiatfonts/ "http://www.houseind.com/fonts/edbenguiatfonts/") [Ed Roman]  
 [http://www.google.com/fonts/specimen/Fontdiner+Swanky](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056/http:/www.google.com/fonts/specimen/Fontdiner+Swanky "http://www.google.com/fonts/specimen/Fontdiner+Swanky")

Ok, thank you very much for this useful information!

Best

David

AFAIK nobody has made this lettering into a font.  
The capital letters are fairly standard Roman letters with pulled out serifs. Fonts that include this feature include Ronaldson

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056im_/http:/typophile.com/files/RonaldsonAsTMW_5765.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ronaldson/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ronaldson/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/canadatype/ronaldson/") and Tiffany 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056im_/http:/typophile.com/files/TiffanyMedAsTMW_5064.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/tiffany/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/tiffany/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itc/tiffany/")  
The other letters are an unusual mix of roman letters with big ball terminals and sloped letters. For some ideas see Everafter Bold 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056im_/http:/typophile.com/files/EverafterBoldAs_anho_4640.gif)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typetrust/everafter/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typetrust/everafter/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typetrust/everafter/") and Oxtail Black 
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056im_/http:/typophile.com/files/OxtailBlackAs_anho__5811.gif)
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/macrhino/oxtail/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/macrhino/oxtail/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/macrhino/oxtail/")  
Don

I was able to find a higher resolution image of the letters and edit it to remove the shadow effect

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317121056im_/http:/typophile.com/files/NoShadow@34pct_6576.jpg)
  
If we ignore the rugged edge effect, are there any more suggestions as to substitutes for all or portions of the lettering?  
Don
